title: Great!
body: So many lovely and helpful volunteers, well organised and very pleasant experience. I recommend this surgery.

title: Fantastic Service
body: I had 5 separate appointments with the Nurse. She was very efficient informing me of what she was going to do, apologised for hurting me but it was not her it was the medication.  I was impressed with her approach. She is very caring, gentle and has a beautiful smile. I would put my life in her safe and gentle hands. Thank you nurse.

title: A First Class practice
body: Came to have COVID Vaccination 19/02/21- From the staff/volunteers in the car park outside, to the staff supporting the nurses & doctors given the jab, plus staff/volunteers helping when leaving, not to miss the cleaners and other staff members who supported and set this up. Well Done, excellent first class job by all. Everyone was helpful, polite, no question that anybody asked whilst waiting inside or out was treated with anything but respect by them all. A hugh "Well done to all the team". So proud of them all. Thank you

title: Vacination
body: Visited the surgery for my vacination and was in & out within half an hour.  The logest wait was the 15 minute sit down after the injection.  Overall an efficient and pleasant experience.

title: Best Surgery
body:
I was privileged to be the 10000th patient to receive the COVID-19 vaccine in this surgery I had my photo taken by the press and was well impressed with the organisation from Jab 1 to Jab 2 always emailed or text and kept updated  all  good Doctors here well done team.
The surgery efforts show throughout and team have worked well thanks to you all.
Dr Anil Mehta and Team.

title: Excellent care
body: I had to take my elderly mother to QEII urgen care today at 4pm I cannot thank the staff enough from the exceptional receptionist to the brilliant nurses who cared for my mum and dressed her leg they were so amazingly caring I felt that mum really mattered

title: Excellent booking system for appointments by…
body: I have used this practice for the last ten years with various disorders of wellbeing, always helpful even if you are unable to see your own Doctor you are registered with.

title: Efficient friendly staff
body:
I recently attended at Fairfield General Hospital for an MRI scan. The staff were very helpful and kind, and I was treated with respect at all times.
My whole experience was excellent.

title: Covid vaccine
body: Incredibly well organised vaccine rollout at Salisbury cathedral, cheerful staff, fantastic volunteers, very slick

title: Poor practice
body: Difficult to speak to a GP, I was told that a GP would phone me on Friday 26th Febuary regarding side effects of Medication I had been prescribed.Waited by the phone all day, no phone call recieved.This surgery offers no support to its patients whatsoever .All the good Doctors have left.I feel totally let down by this practice.

author: Rac23
title: GP Services
body:
Requested change contraception on the advice of a consultant gynaecologist.  
GP not providing removal of implant even though I am bleeding, have headaches and other side effects.  
Given more medication in the form of oral hormone but these have been ineffective and made me feel even worse.  
Booked apt with GP.  
Swab attempted but due to bleeding this was not possible.  
Nothing else offered to ease bleeding.  
Again told Gp don't have the time to take out implants.  
Left GP surgery very distressed.  
The examination room had a broken window blind. I felt exposed and uncared for during the whole procedure.  
I have now booked to have my implant removed at Kingsbridge Private Hospital at a cost of £133.  
I am 22 years old and feel completely let down by my GP service in this matter.

author: Tblasdale
title: Hard-to-reach primary care
body:
My husband is a patient at Wessex Road surgery. He needed a repeat prescription for his antidepressants as he’d lost his paper copy.  
He tried to call the surgery and it is so geared up to COVID it’s like nothing else is happening in the world. We called five times at 2:30 and after the tedious COVID talk the phone just rings and then goes dead.  
For someone not feeling great in the first place this is pretty stressful. What happened to cheerful voices being helpful on reception? Where is everyone? Speaking to anyone now is like the krypton factor, and doctors are like some holy grail that us mere mortals must solve endless problems and jump through computer-based hoops to access help.  
This is also my experience as I’ve had to endure the e-consult drama. If I wasn’t computer literate there would be no way I could navigate these over complicated portals. I have to do everything for my 87 year old mother.  
Just my thoughts. Thank you.

author: Oprah
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Family restricted from time with father at end stages
body:
Family restricted from spending valuable time with father at end stages of life.  
I can appreciate restrictions need to be enforced to minimise the risk of Covid-19 transmission in order to protect the population and particularly those who are vulnerable. However, I feel that the guidance regarding relatives being with a loved one at end of life should be reviewed and appropriately amended. Due to Covid-19 regulations, relatives are prohibited from being with their loved one at end stages of life. As a family we were given 10 minutes to be with dad, 3 days prior to his death.  
I fully appreciate that we were fortunate to get this short time unlike other relatives that experienced loss in the earlier stages of this pandemic.  
  
Personally I feel the terminal stage is when a patient needs their loved ones most. There appears to be no advocate to act on the behalf of the patient or relative to challenge such cruel regulations. Even staff struggle to come to terms with these guidelines. It seems, it is a matter of just accepting these rules. Yet there is evidence to suggest that there are inconsistencies in adhering to the guidelines across the board.  
I am employed as a health professional by the HSC trust and am up to date with infection control policies. If I worked a shift I could have had access to my dad in his final days, hours and minutes of his life. Yet as relative this privilege was denied. AHP's are not advised to isolate after leaving the work place. Why should relatives, if they are willing to adhere to infection control policies be treated any differently?  
Shorty after my dads funeral I watched very powerful footage on Channel 4, which covered the care undertaken in CAH 2 North Respiratory. I acknowledge that it is important to make the public aware of the seriousness of Covid-19 virus and to also highlight the impact that it has on staff-whom I must add are doing a great job under extreme pressure. However, it was disheartening to think that, camera crew, reporters etc. are allowed lengthy access to a ward but relatives are not.  
Nothing will ever give us back this precious time that dad and his family lost out on, but I hope that I can maybe be a voice for any vulnerable patient or relative that may unfortunately face such a stressful, sad experience in the near future.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Isabella22
title: Doctor an hour late for scheduled appointment
body:
I had a mental health appointment by telephone ( due to Covid restrictions) I was first to be seen at 9am that morning but by 10am I had to phone the clinic as I was still waiting. . I believed that I had somehow missed a day, but the receptionist told me that the doctor was in the clinic and that I was still first to be seen.  
An hour and a quarter after the scheduled time for the appointment, the doctor called me. They said that they had been discussing a different case with a colleague. I asked whether they realised that the service was dealing with people who are mentally ill and need structure and reassurance. They said they did. I asked whether it had ever it had ever crossed their mind to get a staff member to telephone me to let me know there was delayed but that they were aware that I was to be seen. They said they hadn't. I said that common courtesy dictates that you keep people who are waiting for you up to date and that it was the height of unprofessionalism.  
The doctor said that they has decided that I was going to do a certain practical therapeutic treatment. I told the doctor that they had not involved me in the decision and had assumed that I lack capacity to decide for myself. In any case, the activity is not one that I would do anyway as I am not interested in it at all.  
The doctor then asked me when I was going to get a job. I explained that I had been medically retired from work on evidence that they had supplied my former employer. I added that while I receive an occupational pension, I still pay tax. I asked them how much more tax they would like me to pay. I told the doctor they were telling the wrong person to go and get a job and that I felt that they considered me a habitual welfare claimant, when in fact I do not claim a penny from the State.  
I have submitted a formal complaint to my local MH Trust ref these matters and have informed them that if I receive no meaningful resolution and way forward I will contact my MP.

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: Autism Parent
title: My son’s battle for Autism Diagnosis
body:
I am posting here as I am absolutely at my wits end due to the lack of support I have received for my son and don’t know where else to turn. I had a traumatic birth and my son was premature. His milestones were delayed and I first raised concerns that I suspected he is Autistic, when he was aged 1. I was told by my health visitor at the time that as a first time Mum, I didn’t know any better and he would catch up. I raised concerns again at his subsequent check ups and was told again that he was “probably fine”. I am a teacher and work with many ASN children so have a professional understanding as well as a personal ones. My concerns were dismissed.  
I spoke with his council nursery who agreed and said they had wondered the same thing but had never raised it with me. I started with a new health visitor and so the process began again of me raising concerns which were initially dismissed by my new health visitor. I took my son to my GP as part of his sensory issues meant that he was refusing almost all foods and was losing weight and dropping down the centiles. Having met him once, she immediately agreed and referred him for an Autism assessment in 2019.  
In March 2020, when he was 4, he was seen by the specialist pre school nurse and she also agreed that he is almost certainly Autistic and placed him on the list for diagnosis. He was discharged from the health visitor when he turned 5 in May 2020. In July 2020 he had a phone consultation with a dietitian who requested bloods to be done. These bloods have never been done. He is still very small for his age and has a very limited diet. We had a telephone consultation with Occupational Health due to the motor skill difficulties he has. She sent us some cutlery and discharged us.  
After a year on the Autism diagnosis waiting list, I’ve been told that I should have been referred to a different team when he started school in August 2020. This did not happen and he is currently in limbo, sitting on the wrong team, still waiting for diagnosis and help and support. He is struggling in school and I am struggling with the weight of fighting for him for five years and being no further forward. I understand services are very stretched and covid has not helped but we need help. I need him to be formally diagnosed so that I can begin to properly access the help he needs in school and beyond. I am so sad and stressed and angry. I feel we are continually forgotten about and that no one cares about the impact this is having on me and my son.

readBy.name: East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: izarse43
title: Waiting room experience
body: I had a member of staff discuss a personal procedure (flexible cystoscopy) in a waiting room with other people setting across from me. I feel confidentiality was breeched and it was embarrassing to have everyone else informed about my procedure, my bladder, my vagina ect. This could have been done in a private area. Not without member of the public staring at me and listening in.

author: Carolmac
title: Non referral after hospital stay
body: My father was discharged at the end of December with about 3 hours notice. He had a catheter inserted and was basically dumped at home. No training or advice given re catheter care and no additional night bags given. After calling for help and several visits from the District Nurses I now have the correct medical supplies. This was not easy to get as every DN visit was someone different and they told me to do different things. His discharge letter stated that he would get a referral to the outpatient Urology department. After hearing nothing for 8 weeks, and several telephone calls later I was informed that no follow up appointment had been made. The clinic only sits once a week so an appointment was made for a weeks time. This level of service is totally unacceptable.

author: Brora
title: I saw lots of inconsistencies
body:
Had 2 visits this week for minor burns to my hand.  
I was anxious to attend as I appreciate there would be lots of changes in procedures as result of COVID 19. I saw lots of inconsistencies in staff with regards to PPE and distancing and waiting room rules .  
Staff were standing in small corridor chatting with no masks  
Staff walking between treatment rooms with mask scrunched in their hand and coffee cup in the other.  
Reception staff were inconsistent . One allowed me to have my mum stay with me waiting ,another said my mum had to wait in her car. One receptionist allowed a carer to move the seat out of its marked section .  
Waiting area seats were not wiped between patients  
A member of staff prepared my dressing then remembered they had no mask on.  
Me and my mum did not feel confident in COVID safety in place . We were looking to the staff to lead by example and be professional in their approach  
  
I am a key worker in an early years centre and my mum is an AHP with NHS Fife really understand the importance of risk assessment to guide good practice.

author: Jesskitty
title: My keyworker
body: I’ve been a client for over 20 years and I’ve just done an opiate detox. My key worker has been amazing throughout all my care. She was always on hand if I needed her. She was a massive support and big part off my life. I’m going to miss her so much.

author: Izzyr58
title: Home IV service kardex
body:
Started with a sinus/chest infection, doctor adviced best to stay at home and get treatment.  
Feeling better than usual

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: EVOLE
title: Son with Learning Disability
body:
Took my 17 year old son for an appointment at RAH in December.  
He had challenging behaviour and hardly left home for years Staff catered for him and us amazingly from parking to appointment. Grateful parents thank you.

author: Davro92
title: Plenty of volunteers on hand
body: Plenty of volunteers on hand to offer assistance and reassurance and lots of people ensuring touch points and seating are sanitised. Very efficient and really well organised.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Worried mother 1
title: This lady was everything a nurse should be
body: My 14 year old son was brought in to the Victoria hospital on Friday morning after an incident, the staff in A& E were fantastic very professional and caring, we were then taken to the children’s ward where I have to praise all of the staff who are an absolute credit to NHS Fife, the one nurse who stood out and couldn’t do enough for myself and my son was the charge nurse of the children’s ward Sharon, this lady was everything a nurse should be caring compassionate with a great sense of humour who put my son at ease straight away, I can’t thank her enough for being her and making us both smile at a worrying time. Thank you Sharon x

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: loubella
title: kind and compassionate care
body: I had an MVA procedure today for a missed miscarriage at the Rubislaw Ward and the kind and compassionate care by the doctors and midwives helped make a traumatic experience more bearable. I would especially like to thank Lesley the midwife and Ali the doctor for the care they gave me and ensuring I was looked after and supported. I will never forget the kindness I experienced today and want to ensure this is passed on to them.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Slice69
title: Excellent care from start to finish
body:
I contacted my GP surgery on Monday morning, as my sciatica symptoms had changed and the pain was severe. I was triaged via telephone and the GP instructed me to attend my local A&E at GRI as soon as possible. Whilst I was preparing to leave for A&E my GP called back to instruct me he had already contacted Orthopaedics who would see me when I arrived. I was worried, but this reassured me, my doctor was trying to get ahead of the game so to speak. On arrival I was dispatched to minor injures but the On call orthopaedic reg was paged. Yeah, I waited a wee while but was examined by very pleasant, confident doctor (Kieran). He wanted to get to the bottom of my pain so pushed for a MRI scan to be done that day. By 1.30pm I had been scanned and sent to the orthopaedic ward. A couple of hours later Kieran delivered the results. I was to have surgery as an emergency admission, but would need to transfer to QEUH for neurosurgeons to operate on my spine. Both Kieran and the Trauma co ordinator on ward 61 @GRI continued to care for me whilst I waited for an ambulance to transfer me. I was informed it may take a few hours for an ambulance to become available, but minutes later, I was on my way to QEUH and the ambulance personnel were reassuring and chatty and, I felt, genuinely cared. Even though they were pretty frazzled nearing the end of a long shift.  
I arrived safely at ward 64 @QEUH and again the care from nursing staff and clinicians from start to finish was just brilliant. I was in theatre by 10.30pm , returned to the ward by 3am, and with everyone’s hard work and excellent care I am recovering well, having avoided the significant life altering issues I would likely have faced without the surgery. There were so many people involved in this and I didn’t catch everyone’s names but my GP, Dr Soo THANK YOU! Kieran and the trauma co ordinator GRI ward 61 Amazing! Thank you guys too. And all of the staff @QEUH on Mr St George’s team and Su from anaesthetics, many thanks. All of the nurses, student nurses, support workers physios and domestic and catering staff on ward 64. Especially Rihanna, Hannah, Tracey and Carla thank you all so very much. Finding the time to comfort reassure and just be kind when all around you is busy, it just meant a lot to me, given I was in a spin with how quickly my situation had developed. Thank you all........it’s not enough......it’s just words.....but your words got me through and it means the world to me and my family.

readBy.name: University of Glasgow - School of Medicine, Dentistry and Nursing

author: ariesyx67
title: Discharge from CMHT
body: I feel my discharge from CMHT has not been a positive experience which is very important to me having had many bad experiences of endings in the past which have impacted me greatly. The care coordinator informed me of my discharge but alas there has been no goodbye meeting or telephone call this I feel is a totally unacceptable way to to treat a patient.

author: Thundercat1010
title: No one contacted us to update us
body:
My 79 year old mother was admitted to ward 33 via a and e following a fall. She was bright, articulate and alert before the admission. I struggled to even get through to the ward to ask after her welfare and when I eventually did, I was just told that she was happily talking to herself. I tried to say that this wasn’t her normal presentation but was ignored. No one spoke to me or the family about my mum and no one contacted us to update us about her care.  
It felt like my mother was being written off and the family were not even given the time of day. We were told that only one member of the family should ring as they were too busy to be speaking to us. We had to wave her off in the ambulance and were then met with a wall of silence.  
My sister and I feel helpless and extremely distressed about the situation but have been unable to address this with the staff on the ward as they are, in the main, unwilling to speak to us. We have no idea what is happening to our mum and know that she must be feeling abandoned and afraid. It’s unacceptable.

readBy.name: Sherwood Forest Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: Jallands
title: Event Recorder Fitting
body: Made to feel at ease. Everything fully explained. All in all a very good experience.

author: jessrai
title: Receiving Reiki after bowel surgery
body:
I’m a cancer patient and after having a tummy ache I decided to contact oncology who said I needed to come into A&E. I was diagnosed with a bowel hernia and after the surgery I felt pretty low .. I could not move for IVs drainage bags etc. Sarah came to see me and performed Reiki on myself, . I felt more relaxed as I was feeling very frustrated as I could not do anything for myself . After a few days I had a few things removed which made me a little more mobile . I had asked Sarah to come and see me again .  
She came to see me in the afternoon and again performed Reiki on myself , well she woke me up when she had finished and I was amazed at how relaxed and positive I felt . I felt like I had weights lifted off me . Sarah suggested that I stay on the bed for a while . So I then woke up 3 hours later feeling very rested , calm and happier .  
I had a such a time in hospital I cannot express, I could see no ones face due to ppe , my family and husband could not visit , i felt on such a low . The Reiki that Sarah gave me really did help me so much and I really look forward to seeing her again for more Reiki . X

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

title: Efficient covid jab
body: This was my first covid jab, and first visit to this clinic. Everything was smooth, from the sms message to the actual vaccine a few days later.

author: mercuryms66
title: Patients journey with chest pain
body: I was admitted into AMIA mid Feb, with chest pain. A frightening prospect, however the care I received in AMIA, was amazing. Staff nurses Amy and Emma, were kind, efficient and despite clearly being extremely busy always had a smile and a few words to all the patients they were looking after. Dr Close also had a lovely manner. Chris from cardiology came across to assess me. I was then moved to ward 109, where again, the care was great, Staff Nurse Dee and Staff Nurse Elaine (up from 104) were so good and in particular Staff Nurse Sam, who was professional, caring and went the extra mile to look after me. HCSW Marion is a gem and I would also like to mention a wonderful lady on the ward called Netta, who works a domestic, this lady is so hard working and yet always had a smile on her face and a few kind words, a true ambassador for the NHS. I had an angiogram (Dr Hogg), and again the staff involved, radiographer Chelsea and lovely nurses (sorry I’ve forgotten your names) provided absolutely first class care and attention. I was then moved to 216, all great team players with the memorable staff for me being Staff Nurse Emily who I witnessed having the patients of a saint whilst caring for a challenging patient throughout the night with a smile on her face and a lovely manner through out. Staff Nurse Joe and Staff Nurse Lynne are hard working, so knowledgeable and caring members of staff. I also managed to fit in an echocardiogram (Anne) and a mammogram Radiographer Angela and HCSW Mandy, thank you so much ladies, for your care, attention, professionalism and kindness. A final mention to the team that brings this all together, the wonderful porters, James, Martin, Christine, and Stuart (orderly from Radiology. ) You all work non stop and the hospital would grind to a halt without you guys. As you can see from the above, with 6 days of care, investigations and attention, there are so many people involved when you are admitted to hospital, (so many more I can’t remember your names, I’m so sorry, but equally important). I want to thank you all for what you have done for me during this admission and for all the other patients that are lucky enough to pass through your care. You can and do make a huge difference to people lives every single day, never forgot that! GO TEAM NHS!

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Verdemar 111
title: Getting advice about Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
body:
Eighteen to twenty four months ago I started to feel on occasions extreme tiredness & fatigue. I put it down to my B12 deficiency kicking in early. I normally get a booster B12 vaccination every 12 weeks. I eventually decided that I have a need to discuss this with my GP, as this fatigue problem was increasing & becoming more common as the months went by. After a number of visits to my doctor to discuss this problem I was referred for an ultrasound scan on my lower abdomen. The conclusion was that I had a large & fatty liver. Was this the cause of my fatigue & tiredness ? The doctors advice was that it was possible & until I receive further consultation & due to Covid 19 restrictions goodness knows when this will happen. And until I receive this consultation I or we cannot be sure. My doctor whom I may add has been most helpful & thorough dealing with my health problems also advised that I could be suffering from Chronic Fatigue Syndrome. My first thought was what on earth was this. To my doctor the comment was what prescription can you give to eliminate this problem. This is when my positive thoughts took a knock, when advised if my fatigue problem is the result of chronic fatigue syndrome there is no cure. All I can do is manage the problem. Easier said than done, particularly when approaching 73 years of age.  
My doctor then put a question to me do I wish to discuss this health problem with an Occupational Therapist. Again confusion reigned when this suggestion was put to me. Occupational Therapist, what is that. The doctor advised that my discussions with the therapist could assist me in managing the fatigue problem. This I agreed to, although I admit I was utterly & totally skeptical of this move. A thought I did relay to my therapist after a few weeks of discussions. Anyway my answer to the doctor was yes of course what have I got to lose by discussing this problem with the Occupational Health Therapist.  
My discussion or should I say my telephone conversation started on 21 January with Miss Corrie, who is located at Viewpark Health Centre. She after my discussions provided me with a a print out which gave an introduction to Chronic Fatigue problem. And more important in my opinion on the print out how to overcome & deal with this problem. One section in this print out was the heading Challenge Distorted All or Nothing or Catastrophic thinking. believe it or not when the fatigue was occurring my thoughts were starting run crazy. I could see no way out of this problem & it was a case of my thoughts my feelings going into overdrive & ever decreasing circles.  
To cut a long story short the advice received from Miss Corrie was very helpful. including the need to monitor my diet, which I may add was not dreadful but could be improved. Gentle & measured exercise rather than go like a bull at a gate.  
To conclude, my fatigue problem is still there & occurs whenever it feels like it. But with the advice Miss Corrie provided, I am more content with myself. I am not saying I have come across with a miracle cure. But managing the problem undoubtedly helps. And strongly recommended to anyone with this problem. Particularly anyone who may be sceptical of having discussions on health problems

author: Dark Brown Eyes
title: Receiving Oxford Astra Zeneca Covid Vaccine
body:
We were very happy with the service we received and the way the staff presented themselves on entry into the surgery and while waiting in the waiting area. I also received the vaccine along with my wife today as she is my Carer.
The only thing is we did not get a 'Don't forget you Covid-19 Vaccination card' as stated in the booklet we received from Dr. Sudell today in the company of a male colleague.
Can we have a 'Don't forget you Covid-19 Vaccination card' sent to us, or can we pick it up as we are not far from the Surgery?

author: Member of Public at Ulster Hospital
title: Receiving Covid-19 vaccine
body:
The process was quick taking 40 minutes from arriving to leaving. The volunteers at the entrance were very friendly and kept everyone correct. The whole process was very smooth and queuing was minimal. Karen administered my vaccine today. Again she was friendly, informative and made it a very comforting experience.
My thanks to all those that participated in my experience today.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Maileo
title: The covid vaccine
body:
I had a fantastic experience from arrival to departure. Everyone was reassuring and put me at ease. As someone who never has to go to the doctors and blessed with good Heath I was apprehensive about all this.
We have the best wee country in the world and the people are the best.
I am almost in tears writing this
Thanks to all

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: filingzp65
title: Covid 19 vaccination
body:
I got my vaccination yesterday. First of all, I didn't expect the car park to be so far from vaccination centre and I was surprised that there was a temporary pathway for people going in both directions which was about a meter wide so it was impossible to social distance.
Also, once in the centre the queues weren't snaking like you'd get in a bank, but all facing forward so I had to walk between 2 queues to get the end of line, again social distancing was impossible. Similar with waiting 15mins after I got injection. Otherwise, all went smoothly.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: tangierene
title: We need a line of communication with staff
body:
My mother in law has been in hospital for 4 months following surgical repair on her hip following a fall at home. My wife has begun proceedings towards obtaining guardianship as my mother in law no longer has the capacity to make decisions about her own welfare. She cannot go home but refuses to go to a nursing home.  
Meanwhile, due to covid, my wife has not seen her mother since the first week of November. Only one nurse in all that time has taken the time to answer my wife's questions about her mother. The rest simply say 'oh she's fine' and offer very little else.  
My mother in law is still grieving for her husband of 63 years who passed away 18 months ago. She's been institutionalized for 4 months now. The psychiatrist who evaluated her told my wife, after they only had that one interview, that she did not seem depressed. When my wife said that her mother might not have been entirely truthful with them, the psychiatrist was quite offended implying that, in their experience, patients never lied to them. When my wife then said that her mother had said several times that she just wanted to die, the response was that a person didn't need to be depressed to want to commit suicide.  
Last night my mother in law asked my wife to bring something in that she could use to end her life. This morning when my wife took clean laundry to the hospital for her mother, she informed the staff person who was sent down to retrieve it about her mother's request. This staff member brushed off my wife's concerns, saying 'it will be in the notes', and walked away. My wife came home extremely upset.  
It feels like the staff don't care about the patients, that the unit my mother in law is on is simply a storage unit until she able to be discharged. Are staff only concerned with my mother in law's physical needs? Are her emotional needs not just as important? What is my wife to tell her aunts when they tell her that my mother in law has also made similar requests of them?  
Many of these questions could have been addressed if my wife was able to visit. But she can't. My wife is the only family member who is allowed to call the hospital. It is extremely frustrating and dissatisfying to feel not listened to, ignored, and not have your concerns validated.  
I know staffing is always an issue, now more than ever, but I feel that they need to designate one staff person to liaise with family, to regularly update them on the patient's condition and progress, and to ensure issues like this are reported to the doctor or other appropriate staff and then get back to the family with a result.

author: Lynda1955!
title: COVID injection
body: I got there in time seen straight away .. it was all over in a few minutes and I never felt a thing ... I just have a bit pain in my arm today ..

author: Ec123
title: Covid vaccine
body: The process was very easy and I didn't have to wait long at all. They explained everything so well and I felt very relaxed. Definitely made the experience easy!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: listenfz79
title: Covid Injection
body: I attended the Royal Victoria Hospital Belfast for my Covid Vaccination was very well organised and the staff were lovely, but the only thing that I found difficult was that you were sitting in a circle and you could see other people getting their injection which made me feel anxious and very uncomfortable there was no privacy would of even been better if there was area with a divider you could go into for your injection.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: JFS
title: Amazing health workers
body: Got my jab.... excellent set up... lots of staff everywhere and all very friendly. Nurse Siobhan was just lovely and I didn’t feel a thing. She put me completely at ease. So delighted & thankful to have got the vaccination and hugely grateful for our amazing health workers. Thank you.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Rebekah1994
title: Getting the covid-19 vaccine
body:
I went for my vaccine as I am a carer alongside my mum. We both were greeted warmly by very busy staff. The system was amazing, very safe and easy. Straight in and when we waited before we could leave we were offered water and some chat with the nurses. It was a really good experience and thank you to the staff, especially our nurse who administered our vaccine Karen. She was lovely and explained everything to us in detail!
Thanks so much for everything you do for us and more.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Stainless Steve
title: Covid 19 vaccination
body: Got my first injection. Very well organised, clean, safe environment.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Pauyz66
title: Problems with my voice
body: About 2  years ago I started to loose my voice with a cough, I kept going to the Dr getting antibiotics and told it would go away, started to get worse so I was finally sent to ear, nose. throat, they couldn't find anything wrong, even though I sounded really bad, so they finally referred me to the voice therapist, I though it will never work, but after a few weeks of doing some therapy with my voice it's helped alot, sometimes it goes but most of the time my voice is back to normal can't thank them enough

author: eridanusct35
title: Treatment of a lesion
body:
I attended Forth Valley Hospital Skin Team unsure of precisely what the treatment would be. I was relieved to find that David would be involved as both my husband and I had been treated by him on previous occasions  
He fully explained what would happen and introduced me to Lisa and then the doctor involved. There was talk of a skin graft being done prior to the main procedure being carried out but in the end the doctor decided to remove the lesion without a graft.This was a very anxious time for me and I was most impressed with the kindness and professionalism of all concerned especially David and LIsa.

title: Poorly performing and no bedside manner
body:
Having been a patient for a while at this surgery I am always anxious when trying to make an appointment. I find the attitude of staff dismissive and complacent
GP appointments appear rushed either keen to get you out of the door or off the telephone 
It feels more like a business than patient care when I’m speaking to them.
My opinion is they have become too large as a surgery and have lost focus on patients
Management also seem disinterested in fixing things
I would like to see a patient survey to rate and suggest serious improvements!
When you phone for an appointment they telephone message encouraging you to go online is very long and all you want to do is speak to a caring empathetic human being.
If you are new to the area and considering joining the surgery as a patient I encourage you to check out other nearby surgeries.

title: manners
body: you knew a week ago that you did not send my prescription to my pharmacy but you did not inform me. I went to the chemist twice only to be told they did not have it. I now am told it is being done today so now I have to wait another 2-4 days before i get it. Is it beyond you to print a prescription off and send it with the driver. I would have really appreciated it if you would have kindly let me know a week ago. manners after all and saves people time and needless journeys, plus half an hour on the phone trying to sort this out. Thankyou.

author: warmgw85
title: Midwifery care
body:
I have today been discharged by the blue team midwives.  
The care I received throughout pregnancy, during labour and while at home with my son was second to none. Everyone I came across was extremely approachable, professional and made me feel safe.  
I ended up needing to be induced and was fortunate enough to be looked after by my community midwife Holly after giving birth, this gave me some continuity of care.  
I will be forever greatful to Holly, Victoria, Guilia, Leanne and student midwife Abbie for keeping me and my son safe through my pregnancy, during delivery and for the care we have received after. As a health care worker myself I am aware of the pressure these girls are under but they honestly provided seamless care and for that I am eternally thankful!  
Overall I had a great experience with my care and IF I have anymore children I would feel safe in the knowledge that these professionals were looking after me.

readBy.name: East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

title: Terrible
body: I’m leaving this review about experiences I have had at this surgery before the covid pandemic struck. Everytime I ring this surgery it is engaged for around half an hour then when you finally get through all the appointments are gone and you get a very grumpy unfriendly lady on the other end. I realise it must be stressful working in a surgery but I have worked in far more stressful jobs with angry customers and I’ve never once spoken to my customers the way I get spoken to at this surgery. Also why can’t you book in advance! every other surgery lets you do this but no, this surgery likes to keep you waiting, getting more and more fed up!! Terrible surgery.

title: Terrible receiptionist's
body: Called at 8.30am for an emergency appointment for my 10 year old child! Got put in a telephone queue and was then told to call back at 2.30pm because all the telephone appointments had been taken. Such a rude and helpful receptionist, let's hope my daugther doesn't have anything serious because that receptionist will be held responsible.

author: localman
title: Minor finger injury
body:
I attended A&E at East Surrey hospital and received excellent care for a minor problem  
Many thanks

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

title: Fantastic service
body: Attended for both my covid vaccinations (as an NHS worker), latest last week - amazing service. So quick and really well-planned. V impressed. Thanks folks!

title: Rude
body: The rudest, most defensive and unpleasant front of house/Reception you are ever likely to encounter.  Instead of resolving issue they argue back and blame you.  It’s like they’re really unhappy people and come to work to be vile to patients.  Shame as the Dr’s and nurses are great!

title: Poor running
body: During COVID when booking an appointment they tell you to be punctual yet they make patients wait despite the pressure of not to sit in the same area. 20 minutes wait and not seen on time.

author: shortand1987
title: Relaxation
body: had relaxation help me to feel relax and help me for rest of the day

title: rude, ignorant reception staff
body: finally got an answer(9.03am) after an hour of "engaged" signal, had to tell them date of birth (twice), when asked why i wanted to see the doctor, i started to tell her, when she said "ok thats done, you'll get a call later," i was still trying to tell her when she said again, "yer you'll get a call later", obviously not bothered about anything i had to say, so i just said bye and hung up, total ignorance

title: 10/10 couldn’t have been better
body:
Made an enquiry via the website.
Family history of osteoporosis meant I thought it would be a good idea to get a bone density check.
Surgery rang me and arranged a telephone consultation for the following Monday morning.
Doctor rang just after 9am.
He was charming and efficient.
Ran through a questionnaire to assess risk, which indicated I would benefit from a scan.
Request put in for me to have one.

Couldn’t really have been improved upon.
Excellent!

title: fantastic response
body: taken by ambulance sunday morning to stafford a&e with very high temp. and loose bowels. ended up on ward 6 where i remained till wednesday when i was discharged- apparently it was some kind of gastro-entrinal infection. this meant that i had to be cleaned many times- with a lot of care and humour. the entire staff were to my mind working way beyond their basic duties. everyone deserves mention- the doctors for diagnosing and starting treatment early,-the nurses for their compassion -the meal staff -the cleaners -all deserve credit. i thank them for the effort they make to look after us.

title: Fabulous!
body: Thank you to the team for their excellent care, attention to detail and reassuring manner. The process from arrival to departure was outstanding. Keep up the wonderful work and stay safe and well.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great Patient support & Service
body: I have used the service ‘Ask My GP’ which has been excellent. You can chat or ask for a call back the same day. I feel that I have been supported and cared for by the nurse I spoke to who was empathetic and understanding.

title: very efficient and patient centred
body:
Very efficient and warm team, vaccination service slick and patient centred.  Good explanations and  thoughtful care. 
Thank you very much

title: Efficient
body: Received letter informing that I was due the routine Flu jab, phoned and booked with ease. On the day I was in and out in no time

title: Great service
body:
Very good experience all round
The Consultant was helpful and extremely knowledgeable. 
Cannot recommend highly enough.

title: Outstanding
body: I cannot rate this surgery highly enough. They all  really care and treat you with understanding and empathy.

title: Efficiently did what it said in the tin
body: I got my invite to come and get a covid jab, I booked it - almost the next day was available!, I bowled up, got jabbed within 10 mins and was away 15 mins later. Very efficient. And everyone was very friendly.

title: Helpful Proficient Service
body:
My wife has needed continuous  support over many years both as routine and worrying more urgent attention. At all times from Reception to professional personnel she and I have been made to feel we are genuinely cared for and have received a timely response.
Allowances must be given for some frustrating delays in telephone bookings due to high demand.

title: Really welcoming and friendly
body: I was really nervous to have a colposcopy, and also nervous leaving my baby for the first time to go into the hospital. The staff made me feel extremely comfortable and really took their time to talk through not only the procedure but to reassure me that they had locked the doors so no one else could come in etc. They were so kind and should be commended for their brilliant work.

title: Excellent
body: All the staff were very caring & helpful from the beginning of the procedure through to its conclusion. My only problem was that the anaesthetic pellet which placed in my eye before the surgery wasn’t removed and only came out the following day when I started using the eye drops. Apart from that everything was excellent. A sick note was provided for my job as well. The procedure itself was very easy and the surgeon put me at ease. I have been waiting at least 18 months for my cataract surgery and from the referral from the opticians to the surgery being completed was just over a month. When I am due to have surgery on my left eye I would definitely use Spamedica again

title: Corona Vaccine
body: This is not my normal surgery but my husband and I attended to get our vaccine. I can't tell you how fantastic our experience was. Everything was so efficiently organised, but at the same time we didn't feel like it was a robotic service. Loads of volunteers, all exceptionally helpful and supportive. The vaccine was delivered expertly and efficiently and the who experience, including queuing at the beginning, took 30 mins, even though we had to wait 15m after our vaccine. I just had to write to say so.

title: Great practice
body: I have been with Grosvenor medical centre for over 30 years and I have never in all that time had a bad experience. All the doctors are extremely helpful, professional and listen to any concerns I have had over the years. The reception staff have always been courteous and polite and have always done their up most to find me an appointment as quick as possible. I would definately recommend Grosvenor medical centre to anyone who are thinking of moving to this practice.

title: Caring practice
body: Smooth and seamless covid vaccination service provided on Saturday by friendly staff and volunteers. Truly a credit to the NHS.

title: Great support
body: I have been registered as a patient at this surgery for most of my life. Five years ago I was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes, I have nothing but praise for the Nuffield House practice team, they are always so supportive and helpful. I am really thankful for all that they do and the patient centred care that they deliver.

title: Amazing. Clean, professional, helpful and…
body: Very helpful staff. The whole process is always so professional and welcoming, excellent staff and fantastic service

author: Monkey04
title: Care after having reaction to Covid jab
body:
I just wanted to thank all in your a& e and on your short stay ward for women for all their help yesterday and this morning when I suffered an adverse reaction to having the first of my covid jabs.  
Although all were run ragged all day and the numbers of patients seemed to never lessen at all over the 12 hours I spent in the a & e and then the further 9 hours I was on Eleanor White Ward I was never rushed, disparaged or left feeling anything other than cared for, even if it did feel that there were times I would have wanted more I didn’t miss any care nor was I not kept an eye on as all those on the wards ran around looking after all of us in need.  
Thank you for being there for us all from the crying children, worried parents, suffering adults, accidents, mental health issues and everything in between I was left in awe of all that was accomplished during the short 24 hours I watched and recovered. Thank you all again from the ambulance attendants, porters, nurses, doctors, cleaners and receptions and anyone else I missed.  
I am grateful to live in a country where we have this access to care and congratulate you all in your hard work and achievements. 💐🌈🏆

title: A caring service
body: Compared to my previous GP practice, Mill Road answer the phone very quickly indeed. I've also found the attitude of the staff interested, friendly, cooperative and responsive and wouldn't hesitate to recommend them to anyone.

title: Disappointing
body:
Attended MAU (maternity assessment unit) on 26/02/2021 due to reduced movement and pain in lower stomach. I was 34 weeks pregnant so it is a very scary time of pregnancy. 
I arrived about 7:30 and got a horrible lady who shouted at me because I didn’t understand what she meant when asking me a question. Then they swapped staff and I was left with another lady who then stood outside the room I was in and told a doctor who was coming to see me what the problem was her words were ‘she isn’t happy with the HCG’ and the doctor and her started laughing and talking saying it’s a machine why not be happy? This made me feel very uncomfortable and I’ll not be very reluctant on returning if I ever have these worry’s again due to them making me feel uncomfortable. In a place like that you should feel more than comfortable attending because they tell you to go their if you have any tiny concern. 
Such a shame.!

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Unreliable
body:
My partner called 111 at 8am this morning. The lady said someone would call back within 2 hours. 4 hours have now passed. 

This is not the first time that this has happened in the last 3 months. In December I was unwell with my asthma. I called 111, said someone would call back, no one did. I then had to ring 111 back to ask what I should do (not wanting to dial 999) with worsening breathing. They then asked me to call 999 to check when a emergency vehicle could get here (this was at 2am, we called 111 at around 8pm). I rang, they asked me if someone else at home could drive me to the hospital instead. 

I just felt really let down and now the same treatment with my partner. I totally appriciate we are in a global pandemic, however both of our health could be/have been at serious risk. 

I cannot stress enough how amazing all NHS staff at the hospital in Ashford Kent were when I was eventually treated.

title: Totally useless
body: Do not answer their phone lines AT All! On three occasions I have tried to call this practice and stayed on the line for three hours. If there was another choice for a practice I would move. I have had a very poor standard of care from this practice.

author: zaqzswxswxde
title: Tilt test
body:
I had an appointment for a tilt test in September 2020. I arrived in good time for my appointment and let the receptionist know that I was there. After waiting for a couple of hours, I asked the receptionist if they knew roughly how much longer I was likely to be waiting - a short while later, the manager of the cardiac investigations service came to tell me that the hospital had not resumed tilt table tests and that my appointment was simply 'forgotten to be cancelled'. I was informed that I would be able to claim a refund for my travel expenses and would be prioritised when the service reopened but have to this day heard nothing back from the hospital's bursar and have not received any other contact from St. George's.  
Whilst the staff were great, clearly administrative failures took place.

author: cruxcb76
title: Well cared for
body: Staff where clear with instructions and well maintained social distancing. The nurse ‘Aoife’ that administered my vaccine was caring, considerate and made me feel very welcome in the environment. The vaccine was completely painless.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: JnM
title: Paramedics attending dad after a fall
body:
I would just like to send my heartfelt thanks to and praise for the 2 paramedics who came/quickly arrived to examine my 94-year-old dad after a fall late at night in Bridlington.  
They were really wonderful with him and stayed 2 hours to make sure his condition was stable before leaving.  
Absolutely amazing people, both.

title: Great service
body:
I have been speaking (via the telephone) with a GP from this practice on and off during Covid for my mental health. He’s been fab and I’ve felt heard on every occasion with practical steps given to help me. 

My youngest son has also had to visit the surgery and the appointment given was quick and the team brilliant.

author: millimeterfx67
title: Covid 19 Vaccination
body:
Well signpost... free parking... well organised... polite and friendly staff including parking attendants, security staff, admin staff and medical staff.  
A well organised calm environment.  
Thank you

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jaypal
title: Partial Knee Operation.
body: Due to the COVID situation, my consultant’s secretary in Ayr hospital contacted me to ask if I would consider travelling to the Golden University Hospital and having my op there. I agreed to this and was referred to the consultant and given a pre op appointment, just a few weeks later. Several weeks after that I was admitted for the operation. All went very well and the all the staff were excellent. I received great medical care, the food was hot and the hospital was spotless. I would like to thank everyone for their hard work, it was second to none. I was admitted on Thursday, operated on Friday and discharged on Saturday evening. I was given all the essential information and medication required, for my continued recovery at home. It is now three weeks since my op and I am recovering well. I have had two follow up telephone calls to check on me. I would also like to thank the practice nurse at my Townhead Surgery for the aftercare. Well done NHS.

author: transfemby
title: Waiting times with the Gender Identity Clinic
body:
I got my first letter being referred to the GIC, I am now on the waiting list. When I first considered being referred to a GIC the waiting list was a little over 3 years, that was only a few months ago. Now, the waiting list is 3 years and 8 months, in a few months I would not be surprised if the waiting list was 4 years.  
This needs to change. More and more people are on these waiting lists, but the facilities, staff and resources are not being increased to meet this demand. It is my opinion that people can die on these waiting lists, not being given the treatment they need.  
There needs to be systematic change. It's clear that waiting so long for certain things is unnecessary. Initial assessment appointments can be done much sooner, administered through a GP. GPs can also monitor and prescribe hormone treatments much sooner. Gender confirmation surgeries would require specialist attention and treatment, so it's understandable for that wait. I feel that this system is inherently flawed and is designed poorly, where a lot of these things could be done outside of this almost 4 year long waiting list.  
Consider systematic change for these gender identity clinics, for the life and wellbeing of trans people in the UK. I beg you.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: First class
body: Hello, I visited the Endoscopy unit on the 26th February mid day and just wanted to thank all concerned for the first class service I received, so I look forward to a return in 2 years time , great staff , many thank's, Jorg Wheelan

author: Bangorgirl
title: Staff were all extremely friendly
body:
I attended the vaccine clinic on Friday.  
The whole process was brilliantly run. Very sleek. Staff were all extremely friendly and in good spirits.  
Well done to all involved in the operation.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: bracene37
title: Very proficient
body: Had a very good experience this afternoon at RVH vacination centre.   Staff were very proficient and had a calm manner even though it’s a speedy process.   Area very clean, bright and seating for all.   Thank you for the HSC for providing an excellent   service today.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jvaccine
title: Brilliantly run service
body: Got covid vaccine number 1. Brilliantly run service, excellent staff. Very efficient! Thank you.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: guideqf84
title: Thoroughly professional and seamless
body: I recently received the Covid 19 vaccination at The Foyle Arena. The whole process from start to finish was thoroughly professional and seamless. The initial booking of the appointment was very simple and dealt with in a very polite and helpful manner. The actual journey through getting the vaccine on the day, could not have been better. The courteous way in which every volunteer or medic supported me and checked my details, didn't seem intrusive but rather that they we making sure everything was in order. Well done to all those involved.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: KGFife
title: COVID vaccination information management and sharing
body:
Hello,  
My elderly relative has COPD and is largely housebound on oxygen. She has been shielding throughout the pandemic and is on the shielding list. She received an appointment for vaccination in early February. As she was unable to attend the vaccination clinic this was switched to a home appointment on the same day as the original appointment. However, no one showed up on the agreed day and no explanation was offered. She got in contact the next day and was initially informed that she was marked as having already had the vaccine, which she had not. She was then told that the home visiting teams were very busy and they would get to her as soon as they could. After waiting more than a week I contacted NHS Lanarkshire and her local MSP directly and was asked to supply contact details for her, which I provided. Both myself and her MSP were assured that the vaccination team was aware of her and would be in touch shortly. When she still hadn't heard a few days later I got back in touch with NHS Lanarkshire and her MSP, and, again, myself and her MSP were offered assurances that the team would be in touch. At the end of February two (lovely) ladies from the vaccination team arrived on her doorstep at 8.30am unannounced to give her the vaccination. While she is relieved to have finally received it, we are all alarmed that she was told by the ladies who arrived to vaccinate her that they hadn't been able to contact her directly to arrange the appointment as they did not have any contact information for her. This is despite her providing it directly, and myself and her MSP both also providing it to NHS Lanarkshire. I absolutely appreciate how busy a time this is for everyone working in the health service and am hugely grateful for their amazing efforts. However, I am writing this to express my concerns about NHS Lanarkshire's data management issues in this case - first, in her being incorrectly marked as vaccinated, and then her phone number not being provided to the vaccination team despite repeated assurances that it had been - which could have had severe consequences for my vulnerable relative.

author: Docbabs
title: Outstanding care for my endoscopy and blood transfusion
body:
I had been to my GP with no energy, struggling to eat and in immense pain. I got referred to surgical assessment unit then transferred to ward B11.  
I cannot commend enough all the staff on ward B11 with their prompt treatment and caring approach. The domestic staff and auxillaries were always on form and the clinical response from the doctors and nurses was outstanding. I cannot praise them highly enough!  
The only negative was when 'agency' staff were on during nights as they were unable to fully assist ward staff with resultant delays in treatment later on during the night.  
I went in feeling like I was seriously ill, got promptly treated and feel the staff should be recognised!

author: Carsw96
title: First Covid Vacination at Ulster Hospital
body: The whole experience was fantastic from start to finish. Run with 'military precision'. All hospital staff and volunteers were very pleasant and helpful which made the experience an easy one.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shanliss
title: Attending COVID Vaccination Centre in Craigavon
body: The process of receiving my vaccine in the Craigavon centre was excellent. I’d like to praise the people working in the centre and say they are doing a fantastic job. The place is extremely well laid out and so safe. Well done to everyone there.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: corridoryj88
title: Impressed by organisation of 1st vaccine
body:
I was very impressed with the organisation within the centre. Danielle who administered the vaccine was friendly and professional, I felt fine afterwards.  
Thanks.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: learningpq39
title: Admission of mother via A&E to Neely Ward
body:
Disappointed I was not allowed entry to A& E to assist my frail 90 yr old mother both physically and in terms of communicating. We were both masked, vaccinated and had no temperatures. Learned later that other couples were together but my mother had to walk in alone. I learned later she was embarrassed, as she had to shout and everyone could hear. She had previously told the nurse at the door that "my daughter is my ears" and I had also indicated the communication difficulties but she still had to go in alone. I had to walk away sick with worry on how she could communicate and whether she would pass out, as she was so frail. She had been bed bound for a full week prior to arrival at A& E. The nurse at the door offered no assistance to get her to reception or even assist her there. This was horrendous for both of us. I learned later it was at least 4 hours before she was given a drink and something to eat.  
___________  
I cannot understand why on my mother's admission to Neely Ward that the Nurse merely showed her the bed. She did not point out her locker; my mother had to ask another patient which locker she should use. The Nurse did not offer assistance in unpacking and nor was Mum shown the bell to ring for assistance, the TV/radio and how to operate these, or if required, provided with earphones. Nor did the Nurse explain about the Ward's portable telephone (not everyone has a mobile). Surely, this should be standard practice on admission? My mother only learned of their existence several days later and the Nurse had no idea if earphones were available. Disappointed to learn that my mother had indicated on several occasions that the handwash in the bathroom was empty and needed replaced. Also disgusted to learn that when my mother went to the bathroom she found a filled specimen tray in the toilet. She had to call a Nurse who removed it by merely placing it on the bathroom floor and left! On discharge the handwash was still empty!  
__________________  
Although the nursing and medical staff within Neely Ward took excellent care of my mother and I appreciate everything they did to get her on the road to recovery, an issue raised would be as follows.:-  
The nursing staff are in soft shoes but this proved ironic as on a regular basis throughout the day and night they were disposing of rubbish or gloves into a bin that had no rubber seal on the rim. Therefore, the bin would bang and the patients would jump. This went on throughout the night which meant the patients were not getting a restful sleep due to this clanging bin. Surely, someone can fit a rubber seal to a bin/bins and avoid unnecessary noise?

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: eridanusrd84
title: Hats off to all the staff working tirelessly here
body: Just had my covid vaccination at the Royal Victoria Hospital Belfast, amazing! such a slick operation in place. Hats off to all the staff working tirelessly here. The amount of people coming through here in the short space of time that I was here is unbelievable.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: cruxpn97
title: Being in Whiteabbey for rehab
body:
I fell on Christmas and was admitted to RVH. I tested Covid positive in mid January, I was transferred to Whiteabbey for rehab.  
I have been happy here. The service is good. However i have been told all week that i am going home but my discharge is delayed which is stressful.  
I would like my walking frame left nearer to my bed.  
The only bad thing is I am a smoker. I was made quit cold turkey for over a month. At first I was offered nicotine patches but I tried these before and they do not work. Staff promised to take me for a smoke this am but it is now 1.30pm and I have not been taken out.  
The staff have been great, friendly and helpful (except for when it comes to smoking).

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: violeteg58
title: Staff at vaccine centre
body:
Very good, fast system for vaccine.
Very friendly, caring staff - especially younger nurses calling out names after 15 minutes of waiting.
Clean bright environment.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Wheaten terrier
title: feeling grateful
body: Received instructions on what to do from entrance to exit. Extremely well organised and friendly staff. No pain on injection of vaccine and feeling very relieved and grateful.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust
